schemes.name: Schemes
schemes.description: Artful deviations from the ordinary arrangement of words. Schemes alter the pattern or structure of language without changing meaning.

tropes.name: Tropes
tropes.description: Artful deviations from the ordinary or principal signification of a word. Tropes turn words from their literal meaning to a figurative one.

figures_of_thought.name: Figures of Thought
figures_of_thought.description: Strategies of argument and ways of framing ideas that transcend mere verbal expression. They shape how audiences think about a subject.

figures_of_sound.name: Figures of Sound
figures_of_sound.description: Devices that exploit the sonic qualities of language -- rhythm, repetition of sounds, and phonetic patterns -- to create memorable, musical prose.

figures_of_amplification.name: Figures of Amplification
figures_of_amplification.description: Devices that expand, elaborate, or intensify a point beyond its simple statement. They overlap between schemes, tropes, and figures of thought.

accismus.origin: Greek 'akkismos' -- coyness, prudery. Used by classical rhetoricians to describe feigned refusal.
accismus.advertising_use: Creates aspirational tension. Luxury brands use accismus when they make products seem exclusive or hard to get. The 'we don't need your business' posture paradoxically increases desire.

ad_examples.example: You never actually own a Patek Philippe. You merely look after it for the next generation.
At 60 miles an hour the loudest noise in this new Rolls-Royce comes from the electric clock.
Think Different -- positioning as indifferent to mainstream computing conventions.

acrostic.origin: Greek 'akrostichis' -- end of a verse line. Ancient poets embedded hidden messages in the first letters of lines.
acrostic.advertising_use: Creates easter eggs and hidden messaging in campaigns. Used for engagement-driven campaigns where audiences discover embedded brand messages or calls to action.

ad_examples.example: Creating campaigns where first letters of menu items spell seasonal messages.
Hidden messages in search result page elements during special events.
Product catalog descriptions with embedded brand values in first letters.

acyrologia.origin: Greek 'a-' (not) + 'kyrios' (proper). The use of incorrect words, often malapropisms.
acyrologia.advertising_use: Used deliberately in humorous campaigns to create memorable word confusion. Can make brands feel more human and approachable through intentional 'mistakes'.

ad_examples.example: You're not you when you're hungry -- characters using wrong words to show confusion.
Deliberate word confusion in character dialogues for comedic effect.
Surreal misuse of language to create memorable absurdity.

adynaton.origin: Greek 'adynaton' -- impossible thing. Classical rhetoric's way of expressing impossibility for emphasis.
adynaton.advertising_use: Makes product benefits feel extraordinarily powerful by comparing them to impossible feats. Creates hyperbolic, memorable claims that audiences understand as figurative.

ad_examples.example: Red Bull gives you wings -- transforming the impossible into brand promise.
It keeps going and going and going -- implying infinite endurance.
When it absolutely, positively has to be there overnight -- implying supernatural reliability.

alliteration.origin: Latin 'ad literam' -- to the letter. One of the oldest sound devices, found in Anglo-Saxon poetry and oral traditions worldwide.
alliteration.advertising_use: The workhorse of sonic branding. Alliterative brand names and taglines are dramatically more memorable. Creates instant phonetic hooks that embed in memory.

ad_examples.example: The brand name itself -- double C creates one of the most recognizable sonic signatures in history.
America Runs on Dunkin' -- alliterative brand name anchors the tagline.
The name's double P creates a percussive, trustworthy sound -- 'pay' and 'pal' linked by alliteration.

allegory.origin: Greek 'allegoria' -- speaking otherwise. Extended metaphor where an entire narrative represents something else.
allegory.advertising_use: Brands use allegory to tell stories that represent larger truths about their products. Particularly powerful in long-form content, brand films, and campaign narratives.

ad_examples.example: 1984 Super Bowl ad -- Orwellian allegory for IBM's computing monopoly.
Keep Walking campaign -- the journey as allegory for personal achievement.
Find Your Greatness -- everyday athletes as allegory for universal human potential.

amphiboly.origin: Greek 'amphibolia' -- ambiguity. When grammatical structure allows multiple interpretations.
amphiboly.advertising_use: Creates deliberate double meanings in headlines. Audiences engage more deeply when they discover the second reading. Powerful for witty, award-winning campaigns.

ad_examples.example: Think Small -- ambiguous whether it's an imperative or a description.
I never read The Economist. -- Management trainee, aged 42. Ambiguity in 'never' and career implication.
When there's no tomorrow -- ambiguous urgency between deadline and existential.

anacoluthon.origin: Greek 'anakolouthon' -- not following. A break in grammatical sequence mid-sentence.
anacoluthon.advertising_use: Mimics natural speech patterns, making copy feel authentic and conversational. Creates surprise by breaking expected sentence structure.

ad_examples.example: A thousand songs in your pocket -- the abrupt simplicity breaks expected tech-speak.
Priceless campaign -- sentence structure deliberately shifts from list to emotional payoff.
Just Do It -- three words that break from any expected elaboration.

anadiplosis.origin: Greek 'anadiplosis' -- doubling back. Last word of one clause begins the next.
anadiplosis.advertising_use: Creates chain-like momentum in copy. Each idea links to the next, pulling the reader forward. Powerful for building toward a climactic brand promise.

ad_examples.example: Power leads to performance. Performance leads to victory. Victory leads to legend.
Science that creates beauty. Beauty that moves the world.
Precision creates confidence. Confidence creates freedom.

analogy.origin: Greek 'analogia' -- proportion. One of Aristotle's fundamental tools of persuasion.
analogy.advertising_use: Makes unfamiliar products accessible by comparing them to familiar concepts. Essential for tech brands explaining new categories and for creating emotional connections to abstract services.

ad_examples.example: iPod: Like having a record store in your pocket.
Your files, everywhere -- like carrying your filing cabinet in the cloud.
Email is where work goes to die. Slack is where work comes alive.

anaphora.origin: Greek 'anaphora' -- carrying back. Repetition at the beginning of successive clauses. Made famous by MLK's 'I have a dream.'
anaphora.advertising_use: Creates rhythmic, memorable campaigns with building intensity. Each repetition reinforces the brand message while adding new dimension. The most widely used repetition device in advertising.

ad_examples.example: Here's to the crazy ones. Here's to the misfits. Here's to the rebels.
Because you're worth it. Because you deserve it. Because it's time.
The Ultimate Driving Machine. The Ultimate in Luxury. The Ultimate in Performance.

antanaclasis.origin: Greek 'antanaklasis' -- reflection. Repeating a word in two different senses.
antanaclasis.advertising_use: Creates clever wordplay that rewards audience attention. The dual meaning creates a 'click' moment of understanding that bonds audience to brand.

ad_examples.example: We live in a world of packages. It's time you had a complete package.
The best or nothing -- 'best' as superlative and as brand identity.
A diamond is forever -- 'forever' as durability and commitment.

anthimeria.origin: Greek 'anti' (against) + 'meros' (part). Substituting one part of speech for another.
anthimeria.advertising_use: Makes language feel fresh and unconventional. Verbing nouns or nouning verbs creates distinctive brand voice. Particularly effective for tech and lifestyle brands.

ad_examples.example: Just Google it -- transforming a proper noun into a verb.
Just Do It -- 'do' as both verb and attitude noun.
Uber it -- brand name as verb, implying action.

antimetabole.origin: Greek 'antimetabole' -- turning about. Repeating words in reverse order. Often confused with chiasmus.
antimetabole.advertising_use: Creates instantly quotable, bumper-sticker-worthy lines. The reversal creates a satisfying click of meaning. One of the most powerful devices for taglines.

ad_examples.example: If you don't look good, we don't look good.
We try harder because we're number two. We're number two because we try harder.
Like a good neighbor, State Farm is there. State Farm is there, like a good neighbor.

antithesis.origin: Greek 'antithesis' -- opposition. Juxtaposition of contrasting ideas in balanced phrases. A cornerstone of Western rhetoric since Aristotle.
antithesis.advertising_use: Creates dramatic tension and makes product differentiation crystal clear. Before/after, old/new, problem/solution -- antithesis structures the most compelling brand narratives.

ad_examples.example: Think Small -- antithesis to the American automotive ethos of the era.
Think Different -- implicit antithesis to IBM's Think.
Yesterday you said tomorrow. Just Do It.

aphorism.origin: Greek 'aphorismos' -- definition. A concise statement of principle. The oldest form of wisdom literature.
aphorism.advertising_use: Distills brand philosophy into memorable, shareable wisdom. The best taglines are aphorisms that transcend advertising to become cultural touchstones.

ad_examples.example: Just Do It -- an aphorism that transcended advertising.
Think Different -- brand philosophy as cultural aphorism.
A diamond is forever -- product truth elevated to life wisdom.

apophasis.origin: Greek 'apophasis' -- denial. Bringing up a subject by denying that it should be brought up.
apophasis.advertising_use: Allows brands to make claims while appearing not to. 'We won't mention that competitors charge twice as much' -- the mention IS the message.

ad_examples.example: We won't bore you with technical specs. Let's just say: fastest network.
We're not going to say our beef is better. We'll let you taste the difference.
We could tell you about our engineering. But the road will do that for us.

aposiopesis.origin: Greek 'aposiopesis' -- becoming silent. Breaking off speech as if unable or unwilling to continue.
aposiopesis.advertising_use: Creates dramatic tension and invites audience completion. The unsaid becomes more powerful than words. Particularly effective in visual advertising where images complete the thought.

ad_examples.example: Chanel No. 5. Need we say more...
Quality never goes out of...
There are some things money can't buy. For everything else...

apostrophe.origin: Greek 'apostrophe' -- turning away. Addressing an absent person, abstract concept, or inanimate object directly.
apostrophe.advertising_use: Creates intimate, emotional moments by addressing concepts, places, or absent people. Powerful for nostalgia campaigns and brand manifestos.

ad_examples.example: Dear winter, we're ready. -- addressing the season directly.
Dear future, we have something to show you -- addressing time itself.
This Bud's for you -- addressing the consumer as absent third party in celebration.

assonance.origin: Latin 'assonare' -- to respond to. Repetition of vowel sounds in nearby words.
assonance.advertising_use: Creates musical, memorable copy that flows when read aloud. Subtler than alliteration, assonance gives taglines an unconscious sonic cohesion.

ad_examples.example: Grace, Space, Pace -- the long 'a' creates aristocratic elegance.
The quicker picker-upper -- short 'i' sounds create energy.
All for freedom, freedom for all -- the 'or' and 'all' vowels rumble.

asyndeton.origin: Greek 'asyndeton' -- unconnected. Omitting conjunctions between words or clauses.
asyndeton.advertising_use: Creates speed, urgency, and punch. Three words without 'and' hit harder than three words with it. The engine of modern tagline writing.

ad_examples.example: Light. Fast. Powerful. -- iPhone product descriptors stripped of conjunctions.
Power. Precision. Perfection.
Impossible is nothing -- asyndetic compression of a larger philosophical statement.

chiasmus.origin: Greek 'chiasmos' -- crossing. From the letter chi (X). Repetition of grammatical structures in reverse order.
chiasmus.advertising_use: Creates intellectually satisfying symmetry. The crossing pattern rewards audiences with an 'aha' moment. Particularly valued in premium and intellectual brand positioning.

ad_examples.example: Ask not what your country can do for you -- the template for countless brand reversals.
Style is what you make it. What you make, that's style.
We don't make sports cars. Sports cars make us.

climax.origin: Greek 'klimax' -- ladder. Arrangement of words or ideas in order of increasing importance.
climax.advertising_use: Builds to a crescendo. Each element raises the stakes until the final, most powerful statement. The architecture of manifesto-style brand films.

ad_examples.example: You train. You compete. You conquer. -- ascending intensity.
This changes music. This changes video. This changes everything.
Protect This House. Protect This Team. Protect This Dream.

ellipsis.origin: Greek 'elleipsis' -- falling short. Omission of words that are understood from context.
ellipsis.advertising_use: Less is more. Ellipsis creates space for the audience to fill in meaning, increasing engagement and memorability. The backbone of minimalist advertising.

ad_examples.example: Think Different. -- ellipsis of 'you should think differently' compressed to its essence.
Drivers wanted. -- omitting everything except the core appeal.
Two words. Everything else -- the brand, the benefit, the lifestyle -- is implied.

epistrophe.origin: Greek 'epistrophe' -- turning upon. Repetition at the end of successive clauses. The mirror of anaphora.
epistrophe.advertising_use: Builds momentum toward a repeated conclusion. Each clause adds evidence, but the repeated ending drives the message home. Creates a drumbeat effect.

ad_examples.example: Yes we can. Yes we can. Yes we can. -- ending repetition as rallying cry.
Work hard. Have fun. Make history. -- each clause ends with a strong noun.
Hear what you want. Feel what you want. Be what you want.

euphemism.origin: Greek 'euphemismos' -- use of good words. Substituting an agreeable expression for one that is harsh or offensive.
euphemism.advertising_use: Essential for sensitive product categories. Transforms taboo topics into comfortable conversations. Also used strategically to elevate ordinary products.

ad_examples.example: Breathe happy -- euphemism for 'your house smells bad and this fixes it.'
Enjoy the go -- euphemism elevating a mundane bathroom product.
Go Commando -- euphemistic campaign for toilet paper confidence.

hendiadys.origin: Greek 'hen dia dyoin' -- one through two. Expressing one idea with two nouns joined by 'and' instead of a noun and modifier.
hendiadys.advertising_use: Gives equal weight to two aspects of a single idea. 'Sound and fury' hits harder than 'furious sound.' Creates a sense of abundance and richness.

ad_examples.example: Beauty and craftsmanship -- hendiadys for 'beautifully crafted.'
Joy and performance -- two nouns capturing one driving experience.
Quality and purpose -- hendiadys for 'purposefully made quality.'

hyperbole.origin: Greek 'hyperbole' -- excess. The oldest and most universal form of exaggeration, found in every culture's rhetoric.
hyperbole.advertising_use: The engine of advertising claims. Strategic exaggeration is the difference between 'good product' and 'the best product ever made.' Audiences understand the convention and respond to the enthusiasm.

ad_examples.example: The Best a Man Can Get -- absolute superlative as brand positioning.
Red Bull gives you wings -- hyperbolic transformation claim.
Melts in your mouth, not in your hands -- implying supernatural heat resistance.

irony.origin: Greek 'eironeia' -- feigned ignorance. Socrates' primary rhetorical weapon. Saying the opposite of what you mean.
irony.advertising_use: Speaks to sophisticated audiences. Ironic campaigns signal intelligence and create in-group bonding with audiences who 'get it.' Dominant in challenger brand positioning.

ad_examples.example: We're number two. We try harder. -- ironic celebration of second place.
I never read The Economist. Management Trainee. Aged 42.
The Man Your Man Could Smell Like -- ironic masculinity.

litotes.origin: Greek 'litotes' -- plainness, simplicity. Understatement through negation of the opposite.
litotes.advertising_use: Creates premium positioning through restraint. 'Not bad' is cooler than 'great.' Luxury and prestige brands use litotes to suggest confidence that doesn't need to shout.

ad_examples.example: Not a bad way to travel. -- monumental understatement for a luxury car.
Not cheap, but worth it. -- litotes elevating price as quality signal.
It's not a car. -- negation that elevates beyond category.

metaphor.origin: Greek 'metaphora' -- transference. Aristotle called metaphor 'the mark of genius.' The fundamental trope from which all others derive.
metaphor.advertising_use: The most powerful device in advertising. Metaphor transfers emotional qualities from one domain to another. 'Red Bull gives you wings' doesn't describe the drink -- it transfers the feeling of flight to a can of caffeine.

ad_examples.example: Red Bull gives you wings -- drink as flight, energy as liberation.
Just Do It -- life as athletic performance, every action as sport.
Your verse -- life as poetry, each person's contribution to the human story.

metonymy.origin: Greek 'metonymia' -- change of name. Substituting one thing for another closely associated with it.
metonymy.advertising_use: Creates shorthand that feels natural. 'Hollywood' for the film industry, 'the bottle' for alcohol. Brands use metonymy to associate products with aspirational contexts.

ad_examples.example: A Crown for Every Achievement -- the crown (metonym for Rolex) represents success.
The Ultimate Driving Machine -- 'machine' as metonym for the entire driving experience.
King of Beers -- royalty as metonym for market dominance.

onomatopoeia.origin: Greek 'onomatopoiia' -- word-making. Words that sound like what they describe. Found in every language.
onomatopoeia.advertising_use: Creates multi-sensory advertising. Sound words trigger sensory memory. Particularly powerful in food, beverage, and automotive categories where sound implies quality.

ad_examples.example: Snap, Crackle, Pop -- the brand IS its sounds.
Plop plop, fizz fizz -- the product experience as sonic identity.
Once you pop, you can't stop -- the 'pop' makes you hear the can opening.

oxymoron.origin: Greek 'oxys' (sharp) + 'moros' (foolish). A compressed paradox: two contradictory terms placed together.
oxymoron.advertising_use: Creates intrigue and memorability through contradiction. Forces audiences to reconcile two opposing ideas, creating deeper engagement and brand curiosity.

ad_examples.example: Seriously Fun -- oxymoron positioning Xbox as entertainment with depth.
Used in multiple campaigns -- the phrase itself is an oxymoron.
Compact luxury -- oxymoronic product positioning for small premium cars.

paradox.origin: Greek 'paradoxon' -- contrary to expectation. A statement that seems contradictory but reveals a deeper truth.
paradox.advertising_use: Makes audiences think. Paradoxical statements demand resolution, creating engagement. Often used for brands that challenge conventions or redefine categories.

ad_examples.example: Think Small -- paradox of a car company asking you to think small.
Used by minimalist brands -- fewer features as superior product.
Don't Buy This Jacket -- paradox of anti-consumerism as marketing.

parallelism.origin: Greek 'parallelos' -- beside one another. Similar grammatical structure in adjacent phrases or clauses.
parallelism.advertising_use: Creates rhythm, balance, and memorability. Parallel structure makes complex ideas feel organized and inevitable. The backbone of manifesto-style brand writing.

ad_examples.example: Thinner. Lighter. Faster. -- parallel adjectives, identical structure.
Fired up. Ready to go. -- parallel energy in parallel structure.
I Will. I Will. I Will. -- parallel declaration as brand manifesto.

paronomasia.origin: Greek 'paronomasia' -- beside-naming. Punning: using words that sound alike but differ in meaning.
paronomasia.advertising_use: Creates wit, memorability, and shareability. Puns reward audiences with cleverness and create headlines that demand a second reading.

ad_examples.example: Make room for life -- 'room' as both space and opportunity.
Beanz Meanz Heinz -- phonetic punning as brand identity.
Finger Lickin' Good -- sensory pun on taste and quality.

personification.origin: Latin 'personificatio' -- making into a person. Giving human attributes to non-human things.
personification.advertising_use: Makes products relatable and emotionally engaging. When your car 'knows' you or your phone 'understands' you, technology becomes companion rather than tool.

ad_examples.example: Siri -- personifying AI as a helpful assistant with personality.
The M&M characters -- candy personified with distinct personalities.
The Gecko -- insurance personified as a friendly, relatable character.

polysyndeton.origin: Greek 'polysyndeton' -- much bound together. Excessive use of conjunctions. The opposite of asyndeton.
polysyndeton.advertising_use: Creates weight, deliberation, and emotional accumulation. Each 'and' adds gravity. Used when brands want to convey abundance, thoroughness, or emotional depth.

ad_examples.example: Taste the feeling and the joy and the moment and the music.
And we wore them and we loved them and we lived in them.
Over rivers and through forests and across deserts and beyond horizons.

prosopopoeia.origin: Greek 'prosopon' (face) + 'poiein' (to make). Speaking as another person or giving speech to the absent, dead, or inanimate.
prosopopoeia.advertising_use: Creates dramatic testimonials and character-driven campaigns. Lets products, historical figures, or even abstract concepts 'speak' directly to audiences.

ad_examples.example: Here's to the crazy ones -- speaking for/as icons like Einstein and Gandhi.
Matthew McConaughey campaigns -- the car seemingly speaking through the driver.
The Most Interesting Man in the World -- a constructed persona delivering brand values.

rhetorical_question.origin: Greek 'erotesis' -- questioning. A question asked for effect rather than to elicit an answer.
rhetorical_question.advertising_use: The most direct form of audience engagement in advertising. Forces mental participation. The audience's silent answer IS the brand message.

ad_examples.example: Two words that launched a cultural phenomenon. The answer is always yes.
Where's the beef? -- rhetorical question that devastated competitors.
Because you're worth it. (Implied: aren't you?)

simile.origin: Latin 'similis' -- like. Explicit comparison using 'like' or 'as.' Unlike metaphor, simile preserves the distinction between compared things.
simile.advertising_use: Makes abstract benefits tangible. While metaphor transforms, simile clarifies. Particularly useful for explaining new products or complex benefits in familiar terms.

ad_examples.example: Like a battery that never dies -- simile as hyperbolic product promise.
Like a good neighbor, State Farm is there.
Like a rock -- product durability through natural comparison.

syllepsis.origin: Greek 'syllepsis' -- a taking together. One word governs two others in different senses.
syllepsis.advertising_use: Creates compact, witty headlines that reward close reading. The double meaning in a single word creates efficiency and cleverness simultaneously.

ad_examples.example: Fly to London and to your dreams -- 'fly' as transportation and aspiration.
Drive safely and drive ambition -- 'drive' as operate and motivate.
Don't leave home without it -- applying to both card and confidence.

symploce.origin: Greek 'symploke' -- interweaving. Combining anaphora and epistrophe -- repeating both at beginning and end.
symploce.advertising_use: Creates powerful, incantatory rhythm. The most emphatic form of repetition. Used sparingly but devastatingly in brand manifestos and political campaigns.

ad_examples.example: When you run, you feel free. When you compete, you feel free. When you win, you feel free.
Every step counts. Every mile counts. Every journey counts.
Real beauty is confidence. Real beauty is courage. Real beauty is you.

synecdoche.origin: Greek 'synekdoche' -- understanding together. Using a part to represent the whole, or the whole for a part.
synecdoche.advertising_use: Creates elegant shorthand. 'Wheels' for car, 'suit' for businessperson. Synecdoche lets advertisers zoom in on the most compelling aspect of a product or experience.

ad_examples.example: Get behind the wheel -- the wheel (part) represents the entire driving experience (whole).
All eyes on the new screen -- 'eyes' representing the full attention of consumers.
The next big screen -- 'screen' as synecdoche for the entire phone experience.

zeugma.origin: Greek 'zeugma' -- yoking. One word governs or modifies two or more words, often in different senses.
zeugma.advertising_use: Creates efficient, witty copy. One verb doing double duty saves space while adding cleverness. Audiences feel smart when they catch both meanings.

ad_examples.example: Open your wallet and your mind -- 'open' governs both physical and mental.
Save gas and the planet -- 'save' serves economic and environmental.
We understand money and people -- 'understand' bridges financial and human.

default_metadata.origin: From the classical rhetorical tradition, catalogued by Greek and Roman rhetoricians including Aristotle, Quintilian, and the anonymous author of Rhetorica ad Herennium.
default_metadata.advertising_use: Apply this device to add rhetorical sophistication to headlines, body copy, and visual concepts. Creates deeper audience impact through deliberate language craft.

ad_examples.example: Think Different -- demonstrating how classical rhetoric powers modern brand communication.
Just Do It -- three words that prove the power of rhetorical compression.
Think Small -- the ad that proved rhetoric could revolutionize an industry.
